Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integrated Characterization of Energy, Clouds, Atmospheric state, and Precipitation at Summit (ICECAPS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
In 2010, the observatory at Summit, Greenland, in the center of the Greenland Ice Sheet (GIS), was expanded to include a comprehensive suite of cloud-atmosphere observing instruments including microwave and infrared spectrometers, cloud radar, depolarization lidar, ceilometer, precipitation sensor, sodar, and a twice-daily radiosonde program. This observing effort was termed ICECAPS (Integrated Characterization of Energy, Clouds, Atmospheric state, and Precipitation at Summit). A continuation of this project is proposed here, with moderate enhancements to include atmospheric aerosol observations. Measurements from this expanded instrument suite will be used to derive critical baseline atmospheric data products including:
* Atmospheric State - tropospheric temperature, moisture, and wind profiles
* Aerosols - concentration of total particles and cloud condensation nuclei
* Cloud Macrophysics - occurrence, vertical boundaries, temperature
* Cloud Microphysics - phase, water content, and characteristic particle size
* Precipitation - type and rate
Together these products, when combined with similar ongoing measurements at Summit, can be used to study processes that impact the surface energy budget and precipitation at the site, as well as addressing questions related to atmospheric stability, cloud phase composition, the persistence of stratiform clouds, and aerosol-cloud interactions. It is further anticipated that these observations will continue to be used by a broad cross-section of the scientific community to promote understanding of GIS and Arctic climate, validate satellite observations, and evaluate model simulations. Graduate students play significant roles in most aspects of this project, gaining valuable experience with polar field work, operating instruments, and processing data. In addition, this research team has developed a unique education and outreach plan to work with students from local schools using simple, proxy instrumentation to help develop their understanding of atmospheric principles and observations, and to enhance the scientific curriculum in their schools via a wide range of outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Anthropogenic climate change is accelerating melting of the Greenland Ice Sheet (GrIS). The surface snow at Summit Station (atop the GrIS) has only melted about 50 times over the last 10,000 years, but has recently melted three times in the last seven years (in the summers of 2012 and 2019). This melting, in turn, contributes significantly to global sea level rise. To accurately predict how the Greenland Ice Sheet will respond to future climate change, a better understanding is needed of how the surface of the GrIS responds to changes in climate. The Integrated Characterization of Energy, Clouds, Atmospheric state and Precipitation at Summit (ICECAPS) project uses observations from Summit Station in central Greenland to better understand how the atmosphere and clouds affect the surface mass and energy budgets of the GrIS. The ICECAPS field campaign has provided the first long-term data record of cloud and atmospheric properties over the central Greenland Ice Sheet. The campaign has been operating continuously for almost a decade (since 2010) and has made valuable measurements at a critical time in Earth?s history. Analyses of these data have provided information on the roles that the near-surface temperature structure and different clouds play in modulating energy at the surface. ICECAPS observations have also been used to assess different weather patterns in Greenland that are important for understanding precipitation, which provides mass (in terms of snow) to the GrIS. Two distinct precipitation regimes exist over central Greenland that are associated with different large-scale weather patterns, which affect both the type and intensity of precipitation over central Greenland. One of these regimes includes both water and ice clouds, while the other contains only ice clouds. The ICECAPS data are also being used to investigate the concentrations of atmospheric gases over the Greenland Ice Sheet, including ozone. These analyses are important for understanding how ozone is exchanged between the tropics and polar regions during sudden stratospheric warming events.

Central Greenland, which is at high altitude (3200 m), is an endpoint of climate in the Arctic and, therefore, studies of this location represent some of the most extreme conditions in the Arctic. Summit Station also has historical significance because it is the drilling site of a deep ice core that was obtained in the 1990s. Thus, the data and analyses provided by this research project are very important for comparing to both regional and global models that predict future conditions for the Greenland Ice Sheet and the entire Arctic. This project has provided the first detailed analyses of processes that are important in central Greenland, where the ice sheet accumulates mass. However, the results obtained here are also important for scientists who study other portions of Greenland (coastal regions) and other processes such as melting and calving of ice. This project supported graduate students at five universities: Washington State University, University of Wisconsin, University of Colorado, University of Oklahoma, and Vanderbilt University. These graduate students gained valuable experience working with observational data and conducting scientific analyses. The project also supported summer research for undergraduates. Many of the students spent time in the field at Summit Station, which greatly enriched their educational experience and has helped to provide the next generation of polar researchers. The ICECAPS project has provided a valuable legacy dataset that will be used by future researchers to understand the rapid changes that the Greenland Ice Sheet is undergoing due to anthropogenic climate change.
